title: Portfolio Website & VPS Configuration
description: Built and deployed this portfolio website on a Digital Ocean VPS droplet, configuring Ubuntu, Nginx web server, UFW firewall with secure port restrictions (443, SSH), and SSH key authentication for enhanced security.
longDescription: End-to-end setup of a production-ready Next.js portfolio on a hardened VPS. Includes repeatable deployment, SSL, reverse proxying, and a CI-friendly process.

steps.title: Provision droplet
steps.details: Created Ubuntu LTS droplet on DigitalOcean and configured SSH keys.

steps.title: Secure server
steps.details: Configured UFW firewall, disabled password SSH, enabled fail2ban.

steps.title: Install runtime
steps.details: Installed Node.js via nvm, PM2 for process management, and Nginx.

steps.title: Reverse proxy + TLS
steps.details: Set up Nginx server blocks and Let's Encrypt certificates with auto-renewal.

steps.title: CI-friendly deploy
steps.details: Created PM2 service script and deploy script for zero-downtime restarts.

title: Home Composting System
description: Developed an efficient composting system using home food scraps (no dairy/meat) mixed with leaves and woodchips in a 50/50 green-to-brown ratio, producing usable compost in 2-4 months.
longDescription: A practical backyard composting workflow that converts household greens and browns into rich soil amendment.

steps.title: Design bins
steps.details: Chose dual-bin layout for active and curing compost.

steps.title: Collect browns
steps.details: Stockpiled leaves and woodchips to balance high-nitrogen kitchen scraps.

steps.title: Begin layering
steps.details: Started alternating layers at ~50/50 green to brown ratio.

steps.title: Turn and aerate
steps.details: Turned pile biweekly, monitored moisture and temperature.

steps.title: Harvest compost
steps.details: Sifted mature compost and returned overs to active bin.

title: Sustainable Vegetable Garden
description: Established a productive vegetable garden growing sweet potatoes, tomatoes, peppers, melons, and zucchini using homemade compost and upcycled materials. Built raised garden beds and climbing structures from reclaimed wood pallets.
longDescription: Raised-bed garden built with reclaimed materials and fed with home compost to reduce cost and waste.

steps.title: Plan layout
steps.details: Sketched bed placement, companion plants, and trellis needs.

steps.title: Build beds
steps.details: Constructed raised beds and trellises from reclaimed pallets.

steps.title: Soil prep
steps.details: Mixed topsoil with sifted compost.

steps.title: Planting
steps.details: Transplanted starts and direct-sowed quick crops.

steps.title: First harvest
steps.details: Harvested early tomatoes and zucchini; adjusted staking.

title: Resolved Running Toilet/Replaced Diaphragm
description: Fixed a running Sloan Optima toilet by replacing the damaged diaphragm that was allowing continuous water flow. Identified the issue through research, sourced the correct 1.6 gpf replacement part, and successfully completed the repair.
longDescription: Diagnosed and repaired a running toilet issue by replacing the damaged diaphragm in a Sloan Optima flush valve. The old diaphragm was compromised, causing water to continuously run. After researching the problem and identifying the correct replacement part (1.6 gpf, not 1.28 gpf), I successfully disassembled the flush valve assembly, replaced the diaphragm, and reassembled the unit. The repair resolved the running water issue completely.

steps.title: Identified the problem
steps.details: Researched the running water issue and determined the diaphragm was damaged. Found helpful resources including YouTube tutorials to understand the repair process.

steps.title: Purchased correct part
steps.details: Bought the correct diaphragm replacement part - Sloan EBV-1024-A for 1.6 gpf (not 1.28 gpf) flush valves.

steps.title: Turned off water and disassembled
steps.details: Shut off the water supply and carefully disassembled the flush valve assembly to access the damaged diaphragm.

steps.title: Replaced diaphragm
steps.details: Removed the old, damaged diaphragm and installed the new replacement part.

steps.title: Reassembled and tested
steps.details: Reassembled the flush valve assembly, turned water back on, and tested to confirm the toilet no longer runs continuously.
